user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Console_CopyOut:
```c
static int32 OS_Console_CopyOut(OS_console_internal_record_t *console, const char *Str, size_t *NextWritePos)
{
    const char *pmsg;
    size_t      WriteOffset;
    int32       return_code;

    return_code = OS_ERROR;
    pmsg        = Str;
    WriteOffset = *NextWritePos;
    while (true)
    {
        if (*pmsg == 0)
        {
            /* String is complete */
            *NextWritePos = WriteOffset;
            return_code   = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }
        console->BufBase[WriteOffset] = *pmsg;
        WriteOffset                   = WriteOffset + 1;
        if (WriteOffset >= console->BufSize)
        {
            WriteOffset = 0;
        }

        if (WriteOffset == console->ReadPos)
        {
            /* out of space */
            return_code = OS_QUEUE_FULL;
            break;
        }

        ++pmsg;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (WriteOffset >= console->BufSize)
        {
            WriteOffset = 0;
        }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Rule 21.17 concerns use of functions from <string.h>. The fragment does not call any <string.h> function, so Rule 21.17 is not applicable. The code wraps WriteOffset to 0 when it reaches console->BufSize, and the write to console->BufBase[WriteOffset] occurs only when WriteOffset is expected to be a valid index. (A separate, unrelated defect would occur if *NextWritePos were already >= console->BufSize, which would cause an out‑of‑bounds access — but that is not a violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 because no <string.h> function is used.)
